Hadley Wickham, Mine Ã‡etinkaya-Rundel, and Garrett Grolemund. (2023). *R for Data Science (2e).* O'Reilly

> This is an open source textbook that can be freely read online at [r4ds.hadley.nz/](https://r4ds.hadley.nz/) but can be purchased from [Amazon](https://www.amazon.com/dp/1492097403).
The textbook was written in quarto and the source code can be found on [github](https://github.com/hadley/r4ds/). This is the primary textbook for this course and the one that we will
follow most closely and comprehensively.


<a href = "https://happygitwithr.com/"><img src = 'images/happygitwithr.png' alt = 'Happy Git and GitHub for the useR' align = 'right' style = "height:175px; padding-left:10px; padding-right:10px;"/></a>

Jennifer Bryan. *Happy Git and GitHub for the R User.* 

> This is an open source textbook that can be freely read online at [happygitwithr.com/](https://happygitwithr.com/). This short online textbook introduces Git and GitHub to data 
scientists and statisticians and illustrates how to integrate them with the R ecosystem/toolkit. 


<a href = "Text Mining with R"><img src = 'images/textmining.png' alt = 'Text Mining with R' align = 'right' style = "height:175px; padding-left:10px; padding-right:10px;"/></a>

Julia Silge and David Robinson. (2017). *Text Mining with R.* O'Reilly

> This is an open source textbook that can be freely read online at [www.tidytextmining.com/](https://www.tidytextmining.com/) but can be purchased from [Amazon](https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1491981652/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=1491981652&linkId=0e92d44b0aa39ab34608ffa582dbd490).
